</li>
</ul>
</tr><tr>
<td class="" style="padding:0 0.1em 0.4em;;">
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Non-standard_positional_numeral_systems&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Non-standard positional numeral systems (page does not exist)">Non-standard positional numeral systems</a></td>
</tr><tr><td class="" style="padding:0.3em 0.4em 0.3em;font-weight:bold;">
<a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_numeral_systems&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of numeral systems (page does not exist)">List of numeral systems</a></td>
     </tr><tr><td style="text-align:right;font-size:115%;"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Navbar&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Navbar (page does not exist)">Template:Navbar</a></td></tr>
</table>
<p><a href="/wiki/Lower_case" title="Lower case" class="mw-redirect">Minuscule</a> (lower case) letters were developed in the Middle Ages, well after the demise of the <a href="/wiki/Western_Roman_Empire" title="Western Roman Empire">Western Roman Empire</a>, and lower-case versions of Roman numbers are now also commonly used: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a>, <i>etc.</i>  In the Middle Ages, a <i>j</i> was sometimes substituted for the final <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a></i> of a number, such as <i>iij</i> for 3 or <i>vij</i> for 7. This <i>j</i> was considered a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Swash_(typography)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Swash (typography) (page does not exist)">swash</a> variant of <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a>.</i> The use of a final <i>j</i> is still used in <a href="/wiki/Medical_prescription" title="Medical prescription">medical prescriptions</a> to prevent tampering with or misinterpretation of a number after it is written.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup>
</p><p>A unique, more comprehensive shorthand for writing Roman numerals was developed during the Middle Ages, which today are called "medieval Roman numerals." This system used almost every other letter of the Roman alphabet to stand as abbreviations for more longhand numbers (usually those that consisted of repetitions of the same symbol). They are still listed today in most dictionaries, although they are long out of use.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="sortable wikitable">

<tr>
<th>Modern<br />number
</th>
<th>Medieval<br />abbreviation
</th>
<th>Notes
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td>5
</td>
<td>A
</td>
<td>Resembles an upside-down V. Also said to equal 500.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>6
</td>
<td>Ϛ
</td>
<td>Either a ligature of VI, or the Greek letter <a href="/w/index.php?title=Stigma_(letter)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Stigma (letter) (page does not exist)">stigma</a> (Ϛ), having the same  numerical value.<sup id="cite_ref-PropN3218_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PropN3218-21">[21]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>7
</td>
<td>S, Z
</td>
<td>Presumed abbreviation of <i>septem</i>, Latin for 7.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>11
</td>
<td>O
</td>
<td>Presumed abbreviation of (e.g.) <i>onze</i>, French for 11.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>40
</td>
<td>F
</td>
<td>Presumed abbreviation of English <i>forty</i>.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>70
</td>
<td>S
</td>
<td>Also could stand for 7, and has same etymology.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>80
</td>
<td>R
</td>
<td>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>90
</td>
<td>N
</td>
<td>Presumed abbreviation of <i>nonaginta</i>, Latin for 90.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>150
</td>
<td>Y
</td>
<td>Possibly derived from the lowercase y's shape.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>151
</td>
<td>K
</td>
<td>This unusual abbreviation's origin is unknown; it has also been said to stand for 250.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>160
</td>
<td>T
</td>
<td>Possibly derived from Greek <i>tetra</i>, as 4 x 40 = 160.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>200
</td>
<td>H
</td>
<td>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>250
</td>
<td>E
</td>
<td>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>300
</td>
<td>B
</td>
<td>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>400
</td>
<td>P, G
</td>
<td>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>500
</td>
<td>Q
</td>
<td>Redundant with D, abbreviation for <i>quingenti</i>, Latin for 500.
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>2000
</td>
<td>Z
</td>
<td>
</td></tr></table>
<p><a href="/wiki/Chronogram" title="Chronogram">Chronograms</a>, messages with a numbers encoded into them, were popular during the <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a> era.  The chronogram would be a phrase containing the letters <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a>.  By putting these letters together, the reader would obtain a number, usually indicating a particular year.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_usage">Modern usage</span></h3>
<p>By the 11th century <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hindu%E2%80%93Arabic_numerals&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hindu–Arabic numerals (page does not exist)">Hindu–Arabic numerals</a> had been introduced into Europe from <a href="/wiki/Al-Andalus" title="Al-Andalus">al-Andalus</a>, by way of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Arab&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Arab (page does not exist)">Arab</a> traders and arithmetic treatises. Roman numerals however proved very persistent, remaining in common use in the "west" well into the 14th and 15th centuries, even in accounting and other business records (where the actual calculations would have been by <a href="/wiki/Abacus" title="Abacus">abacus</a>). Their eventual <i>almost</i> complete replacement by their more convenient "Arabic" equivalents happened quite gradually, in fact Roman numerals are still used today in several niche contexts. A few examples of their current use are:
</p>
<div class="floatright"><a href="/wiki/File:Carlos_IV_Coin.jpg" title="File:Carlos IV Coin.jpg">Spanish Real using &quot;IIII&quot; instead of IV</a></div>
<ul>
<li> Names of monarchs and Popes, e.g. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Elizabeth_II&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Elizabeth II (page does not exist)">Elizabeth II</a> of the <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom" title="United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pope_Benedict_XVI" title="Pope Benedict XVI">Pope Benedict XVI</a>. These are referred to as <a href="/wiki/Regnal_number" title="Regnal number">regnal numbers</a>; e.g. "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a>" is pronounced "the second". This tradition began in Europe sporadically in the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a>, gaining widespread use in England only during the reign of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Henry_VIII&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Henry VIII (page does not exist)">Henry VIII</a>. Previously, the monarch was not known by numeral but by an <a href="/wiki/Epithet" title="Epithet">epithet</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Edward_the_Confessor" title="Edward the Confessor">Edward the Confessor</a>. Some monarchs (e.g. <a href="/wiki/Charles_IV_of_Spain" title="Charles IV of Spain">Charles IV of Spain</a> and <a href="/wiki/Louis_XIV_of_France" title="Louis XIV of France">Louis XIV of France</a>) seem to have preferred the use of IIII instead of IV on their coinage - unless this was a whim of the designer.   
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/Suffix_(name)#Generational_titles" title="Suffix (name)">Generational suffixes</a>, particularly seen in the USA, for people who share the same name across generations, for example <a href="/wiki/William_Howard_Taft_IV" title="William Howard Taft IV">William Howard Taft IV</a>.
</li>
<li> The year of production of films, television shows and other works of art within the work itself. It has been suggested (by <a href="/wiki/BBC_News" title="BBC News">BBC News</a>, perhaps facetiously) that this was originally done "in an attempt to disguise the age of films or television programmes."<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> Outside reference to the work will use regular Hindu–Arabic numerals.
</li>
<li> Hour marks on timepieces. In this context 4 is usually written <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a>.
</li>
</ul>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:CuttySarkRomNum.jpg" title="File:CuttySarkRomNum.jpg">File:CuttySarkRomNum.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Roman numbers on stern of <i><a href="/wiki/Cutty_Sark" title="Cutty Sark">Cutty Sark</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Greenwich" title="Greenwich">Greenwich</a>, showing <a href="/w/index.php?title=Draft_(hull)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Draft (hull) (page does not exist)">draft</a> in feet.</div></div></div>
<ul>
<li> The year of construction on building faces and <a href="/wiki/Cornerstone" title="Cornerstone">cornerstones</a>.
</li>
<li> Page numbering of prefaces and introductions of books.
</li>
<li> Book volume and chapter numbers.
</li>
<li> Sequels of movies, video games, and other works. (as in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jaws_IV&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jaws IV (page does not exist)">Jaws IV</a>).
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Outline_(summary)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Outline (summary) (page does not exist)">Outlines</a>, which use numbers to show hierarchical relationships.
</li>
<li> Occurrences of a recurring grand event, for instance:
<ul>
<li> The <a href="/wiki/Summer_Olympic_Games" title="Summer Olympic Games">Summer</a> and <a href="/wiki/Winter_Olympic_Games" title="Winter Olympic Games">Winter Olympic Games</a> (e.g. the XXI Olympic Winter Games; the Games of the XXX Olympiad)
</li>
<li> The <a href="/wiki/Super_Bowl" title="Super Bowl">Super Bowl</a>, the annual championship game of the <a href="/wiki/National_Football_League" title="National Football League">National Football League</a> (e.g. Super Bowl XLVII)
</li>
<li> <a href="/wiki/WrestleMania" title="WrestleMania">WrestleMania</a>, the annual <a href="/wiki/Professional_wrestling" title="Professional wrestling">professional wrestling</a> event for the <a href="/wiki/WWE" title="WWE">WWE</a> (e.g. the forthcoming <a href="/w/index.php?title=WrestleMania_XXX&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="WrestleMania XXX (page does not exist)">WrestleMania XXX</a>)
</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<p>In <a href="/wiki/Astronomy" title="Astronomy">astronomy</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Natural_satellite" title="Natural satellite">natural satellites</a> or "moons" of the <a href="/wiki/Planet" title="Planet">planets</a> are traditionally designated by capital Roman numerals.
</p><p>In <a href="/wiki/Chemistry" title="Chemistry">chemistry</a>, Roman numerals are often used to denote the <a href="/wiki/Group_(periodic_table)" title="Group (periodic table)">groups</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Periodic_table" title="Periodic table">periodic table</a>. They are also used in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=IUPAC_nomenclature_of_inorganic_chemistry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="IUPAC nomenclature of inorganic chemistry (page does not exist)">IUPAC nomenclature of inorganic chemistry</a>, for the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Oxidation_number&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Oxidation number (page does not exist)">oxidation number</a> of <a href="/wiki/Cation" title="Cation" class="mw-redirect">cations</a> which can take on several different positive charges. They are also used for naming <a href="/wiki/Phase_(matter)" title="Phase (matter)">phases</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Polymorphism_(materials_science)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Polymorphism (materials science) (page does not exist)">polymorphic</a> <a href="/wiki/Crystal" title="Crystal">crystals</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Ice" title="Ice">ice</a>.
</p><p>In earthquake <a href="/wiki/Seismology" title="Seismology">seismology</a>, Roman numerals are used to designate degrees of the <a href="/wiki/Mercalli_intensity_scale" title="Mercalli intensity scale">Mercalli intensity scale</a>.
</p><p>{{#invoke:anchor|main}}In <a href="/wiki/Music_theory" title="Music theory">music theory</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Diatonic_function" title="Diatonic function">diatonic functions</a> are identified using Roman numerals. See: <a href="/w/index.php?title=Roman_numeral_analysis&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Roman numeral analysis (page does not exist)">Roman numeral analysis</a>.
</p><p>In musical performance practice, individual strings of stringed instruments, such as the <a href="/wiki/Violin" title="Violin">violin</a>, are often denoted by Roman numerals, with higher numbers denoting lower strings.
</p><p>In photography, Roman numerals (with zero) are used to denote varying levels of brightness when using the <a href="/wiki/Zone_System" title="Zone System">Zone System</a>.
</p><p>In <a href="/wiki/Tarot" title="Tarot">Tarot</a>, Roman numerals (with zero) are also used to denote the cards of the Major Arcana.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_non-English-speaking_usage">Modern non-English-speaking usage</span></h4>
<p>Capital Roman numerals are still occasionally used to denote <b>centuries</b> (e.g., <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a></i> refers to the eighteenth century) in English. This style is much more widely followed in continental Europe.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Yeltsin-authograph-1988.gif" title="File:Yeltsin-authograph-1988.gif">File:Yeltsin-authograph-1988.gif</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Boris_Yeltsin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Boris Yeltsin (page does not exist)">Boris Yeltsin</a>'s autograph, 10 November 1988. The month is specified by "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a>" rather than "11".</div></div></div>
<p>In many European countries mixed Roman and Hindu-Arabic numerals are used to record <b>dates</b> (especially in formal letters and official documents, but also on tombstones). The month is written in Roman numerals while the day is in Hindu-Arabic numerals: 14. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a>. 1789 is 14 June 1789. 
</p><p>In parts of Europe it is conventional to employ Roman numerals to represent the <i>days of the week</i> in hours-of-operation signs displayed in windows or on doors of businesses,<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup> and also sometimes in railway and bus timetables. Monday is represented by <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a></i>, which is the initial day of the week. Sunday is represented by <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a></i>, which is the final day of the week. The hours of operation signs are tables composed of two columns where the left column is the day of the week in Roman numerals and the right column is a range of hours of operation from starting time to closing time. The following example hours-of-operation table would be for a business whose hours of operation are 9:30&#160;AM to 5:30&#160;PM on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Thursdays; 9:30&#160;AM to 7:00&#160;PM on Tuesdays and Fridays; and 9:30&#160;AM to 1:00&#160;PM on Saturdays; and which is closed on Sundays.
</p>
<table class="wikitable">

<tr>
<td style="text-align:center;"> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a>
</td>
<td align="center"> 9:30–17:30
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:center;"> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a>
</td>
<td align="center"> 9:30–19:00
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:center;"> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a>
</td>
<td align="center"> 9:30–17:30
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:center;"> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a>
</td>
<td align="center"> 9:30–17:30
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:center;"> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a>
</td>
<td align="center"> 9:30–19:00
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:center;"> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a>
</td>
<td align="center"> 9:30–13:00
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td style="text-align:center;"> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a>
</td>
<td align="center"> —
</td></tr></table>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:S6002447_cropped.jpg" title="File:S6002447 cropped.jpg">File:S6002447 cropped.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Sign at km. 17·9 on route SS4 Salaria north of Rome</div></div></div>
<p>In several European countries Roman numerals are used for <a href="/wiki/Floor_numbering" title="Floor numbering" class="mw-redirect">floor numbering</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup>  For instance, apartments in central <a href="/wiki/Amsterdam" title="Amsterdam">Amsterdam</a> are indicated as <i>138-<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a></i>, with both an Hindu-Arabic numeral (number of the block or house) and a Roman numeral (floor number). The apartment on the ground floor is indicated as '<span lang="nl">138-huis</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>'.
</p><p>In <a href="/wiki/Italy" title="Italy">Italy</a>, where roads outside built-up areas have <a href="/wiki/Milestone" title="Milestone">kilometer signs</a>, major roads and motorways also mark 100-metre subdivisionals, using Roman numerals from I to IX for the smaller intervals.  The sign IX | 17 thus marks km. 17·900.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Special_values">Special values</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Zero">Zero</span></h3>
<p>The number <a href="/wiki/0_(number)" title="0 (number)">zero</a> does not have its own Roman numeral, but the word <i>nulla</i> (the <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a> word meaning "none") was used by medieval <a href="/wiki/Computus" title="Computus">computists</a> in lieu of 0.  <a href="/wiki/Dionysius_Exiguus" title="Dionysius Exiguus">Dionysius Exiguus</a> was known to use <i>nulla</i> alongside Roman numerals in 525.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup>  About 725, <a href="/wiki/Bede" title="Bede">Bede</a> or one of his colleagues used the letter <a href="/wiki/N" title="N">N</a>, the initial of <i>nulla</i>, in a table of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Epacts&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Epacts (page does not exist)">epacts</a>, all written in Roman numerals.<sup id="cite_ref-zero_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-zero-29">[29]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fractions">Fractions</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Vecchi_003.jpg" title="File:Vecchi 003.jpg">File:Vecchi 003.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A <span lang="la"><i><a href="/wiki/Triens" title="Triens">triens</a></i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> coin (1/3 or 4/12 of an <span lang="la"><i>as</i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>). Note the four dots •••• indicating its value.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Semisse.jpg" title="File:Semisse.jpg">File:Semisse.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A <span lang="la"><i><a href="/wiki/Semis" title="Semis">semis</a></i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> coin (1/2 or 6/12 of an <span lang="la"><i>as</i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>). Note the S indicating its value.</div></div></div>
<p>Though the Romans used a <a href="/wiki/Decimal" title="Decimal">decimal</a> system for whole numbers, reflecting how they counted in Latin, they used a <a href="/wiki/Duodecimal" title="Duodecimal">duodecimal</a> system for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rational_number&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rational number (page does not exist)">fractions</a>, because the <a href="/wiki/Divisibility" title="Divisibility" class="mw-redirect">divisibility</a> of twelve <span class="nowrap">(12 = 3 × 2 × 2)</span> makes it easier to handle the common <a href="/wiki/Fraction_(mathematics)" title="Fraction (mathematics)">fractions</a> of 1/3 and 1/4 than does a system based on ten <span class="nowrap">(10 = 2 × 5).</span> On <a href="/wiki/Coin" title="Coin">coins</a>, many of which had values that were <a href="/wiki/Duodecimal" title="Duodecimal">duodecimal</a> fractions of the unit <span lang="la"><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=As_(coin)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="As (coin) (page does not exist)">as</a></i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>, they used a tally-like notational system based on twelfths and halves. A dot (•) indicated an <span lang="la"><i>uncia</i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> "twelfth", the source of the English words <i>inch</i> and <i>ounce</i>; dots were repeated for fractions up to five twelfths. Six twelfths (one half) was abbreviated as the letter S for <span lang="la"><i>semis</i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> "half". <i>Uncia</i> dots were added to S for fractions from seven to eleven twelfths, just as tallies were added to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a> for whole numbers from six to nine.<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup>
</p><p>Each of these fractions had a name, which was also the name of the corresponding coin:
</p>
<table class="wikitable">

<tr>
<th>Fraction
</th>
<th>Roman Numeral
</th>
<th>Name (nominative and genitive)
</th>
<th>Meaning
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td> 1/12
</td>
<td> •
</td>
<td> <span lang="la"><i><a href="/wiki/Uncia_(coin)" title="Uncia (coin)">uncia, unciae</a></i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>
</td>
<td> "ounce"
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 2/12 = 1/6
</td>
<td> •• or <b>:</b>
</td>
<td> <span lang="la"><i><a href="/wiki/Sextans_(coin)" title="Sextans (coin)">sextans, sextantis</a></i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>
</td>
<td> "sixth"
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 3/12 = 1/4
</td>
<td> ••• or <b>∴</b>
</td>
<td> <span lang="la"><i><a href="/wiki/Quadrans" title="Quadrans">quadrans, quadrantis</a></i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>
</td>
<td> "quarter"
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 4/12 = 1/3
</td>
<td> •••• or <b>::</b>
</td>
<td> <span lang="la"><i>triens, trientis</i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>
</td>
<td> "third"
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 5/12
</td>
<td> ••••• or <b>:·:</b>
</td>
<td> <span lang="la"><i><a href="/wiki/Quincunx_(Roman_coin)" title="Quincunx (Roman coin)">quincunx, quincuncis</a></i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>
</td>
<td> "five-ounce" (<i>quinque unciae</i> → <i>quincunx</i>)
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 6/12 = 1/2
</td>
<td> S
</td>
<td> <span lang="la"><i>semis, semissis</i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>
</td>
<td> "half"
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 7/12
</td>
<td> S•
</td>
<td> <span lang="la"><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Septunx&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Septunx (page does not exist)">septunx, septuncis</a></i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>
</td>
<td> "seven-ounce" (<i>septem unciae</i> → <i>septunx</i>)
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 8/12 = 2/3
</td>
<td> S•• or S<b>:</b>
</td>
<td> <span lang="la"><i><a href="/wiki/Bes_(coin)" title="Bes (coin)">bes, bessis</a></i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>
</td>
<td> "twice" (as in "twice a third")
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 9/12 = 3/4
</td>
<td> S••• or S<b>:·</b>
</td>
<td> <span lang="la"><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Dodrans&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dodrans (page does not exist)">dodrans, dodrantis</a></i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a><br /><b>or</b> <span lang="la"><i>nonuncium, nonuncii</i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>
</td>
<td> "less a quarter" (<i>de-quadrans</i> → <i>dodrans</i>)<br /><b>or</b> "ninth ounce" (<i>nona uncia</i> → <i>nonuncium</i>)
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 10/12 = 5/6
</td>
<td> S•••• or S<b>::</b>
</td>
<td> <span lang="la"><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Dextans&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dextans (page does not exist)">dextans, dextantis</a></i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a><br /><b>or</b> <span lang="la"><i>decunx, decuncis</i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>
</td>
<td> "less a sixth" (<i>de-sextans</i> → <i>dextans</i>)<br /><b>or</b> "ten ounces" (<i>decem unciae</i> → <i>decunx</i>)
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 11/12
</td>
<td> S••••• or S<b>:·:</b>
</td>
<td> <span lang="la"><i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Deunx&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Deunx (page does not exist)">deunx, deuncis</a></i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>
</td>
<td> "less an ounce" (<i>de-uncia</i> → <i>deunx</i>)
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> 12/12 = 1
</td>
<td> I
</td>
<td> <span lang="la"><i><a href="/wiki/As_(Roman_coin)" title="As (Roman coin)">as, assis</a></i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>
</td>
<td> "unit"
</td></tr></table>
<p>The arrangement of the dots was variable and not necessarily linear. Five dots arranged like (:·:) (as on the face of a <a href="/wiki/Dice" title="Dice">die</a>) are known as a <a href="/wiki/Quincunx" title="Quincunx">quincunx</a> from the name of the Roman fraction/coin. The Latin words <i>sextans</i> and <i>quadrans</i> are the source of the English words sextant and quadrant.
</p><p>Other Roman fractions include the following:
</p>
<ul>
<li> 1/8 <span lang="la"><i>sescuncia, sescunciae</i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> (from <i><a href="/wiki/Numeral_prefix" title="Numeral prefix">sesqui-</a></i> + <i>uncia</i>, i.e. 1½ uncias), represented by a sequence of the symbols for the semuncia and the uncia.
</li>
<li> 1/24 <span lang="la"><i>semuncia, semunciae</i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> (from <i><a href="/wiki/Numeral_prefix" title="Numeral prefix">semi-</a></i> + <i>uncia</i>, i.e. ½ uncia), represented by several variant glyphs deriving from the shape of the <a href="/wiki/Sigma" title="Sigma">Greek letter Sigma</a> (<span class="Unicode">Σ</span>), one variant resembling the <a href="/wiki/Pound_sign" title="Pound sign">pound sign</a> (<span class="Unicode">£</span>) without the horizontal line(s) and another resembling the <a href="/wiki/Ukrainian_Ye" title="Ukrainian Ye">Cyrillic letter (<span class="Unicode">Є</span>)</a>.
</li>
<li> 1/36 <span lang="la"><i>binae sextulae, binarum sextularum</i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> ("two sextulas") or <span lang="la"><i><a href="/wiki/Duella" title="Duella">duella</a>, duellae</i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>, represented by (ƧƧ), a sequence of two <a href="/w/index.php?title=%C6%A7&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ƨ (page does not exist)">reversed Ss</a>.
</li>
<li> 1/48 <span lang="la"><i>sicilicus, sicilici</i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>, represented by (<span class="Unicode">Ɔ</span>), a reversed C.
</li>
<li> 1/72 <span lang="la"><i>sextula, sextulae</i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> (1/6 of an uncia), represented by (<span class="Unicode">Ƨ</span>), a reversed S.
</li>
<li> 1/144 = 12<sup>−2</sup> <span lang="la"><i>dimidia sextula, dimidiae sextulae</i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> ("half a sextula"), represented by (<span class="Unicode">ƻ</span>), a reversed S crossed by a horizontal line.
</li>
<li> 1/288 <span lang="la"><i>scripulum, scripuli</i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a> (a <a href="/wiki/Apothecaries%27_system" title="Apothecaries' system">scruple</a>), represented by the symbol (<span class="Unicode">℈</span>).
</li>
<li> 1/1728 = 12<sup>−3</sup> <span lang="la"><i>siliqua, siliquae</i></span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Category_handler&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Category handler (page does not exist)">Template:Category handler</a>, represented by a symbol resembling closing guillemets (<span class="Unicode">»</span>).
</li>
</ul>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Large_numbers">Large numbers</span></h3>
<p>{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Unreferenced section |date=__DATE__ |$B=
{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Unreferenced |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Ambox&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Ambox (page does not exist)">Template:Ambox</a>
}}
}}
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Westerkerk_MDCXXX.jpg" title="File:Westerkerk MDCXXX.jpg">File:Westerkerk MDCXXX.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">1630 on the <a href="/wiki/Westerkerk" title="Westerkerk">Westerkerk</a> in Amsterdam</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Roman_numerals_Bungus_1584-1585.png" title="File:Roman numerals Bungus 1584-1585.png">File:Roman numerals Bungus 1584-1585.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Roman numerals, 16th century</div></div></div>
<p>In the Middle Ages, a horizontal line was used above a particular numeral to represent one thousand times that numeral, and additional vertical lines on both sides of the numeral to denote one hundred times the number, as in these examples:
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Overline&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Overline (page does not exist)">Template:Overline</a> for <a href="/wiki/1000_(number)" title="1000 (number)">one thousand</a>
</li>
<li> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Overline&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Overline (page does not exist)">Template:Overline</a> for <a href="/wiki/5000_(number)" title="5000 (number)">five thousand</a>
</li>
<li> |<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Overline&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Overline (page does not exist)">Template:Overline</a>| for <a href="/wiki/100000_(number)" title="100000 (number)">one hundred thousand</a>
</li>
<li> |<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Overline&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Overline (page does not exist)">Template:Overline</a>| for five hundred thousand
</li>
</ul>
<p>The same overline was also used with a different meaning, to clarify that the characters were numerals. Sometimes both underline and overline were used, e.&#160;g. <u><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Overline&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Overline (page does not exist)">Template:Overline</a></u>, and in certain (<a href="/wiki/Serif" title="Serif">serif</a>) <a href="/wiki/Typeface" title="Typeface">typefaces</a>, particularly <a href="/wiki/Times_New_Roman" title="Times New Roman">Times New Roman</a>, the capital letters when used without spaces simulates the appearance of the under/over bar, e.g. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a>.
</p><p>Sometimes 500, usually D, was written as original |Ɔ, while 1,000, usually M, was written as original C|Ɔ. This is a system of encasing numbers to denote thousands (imagine the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rns</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rns</a> as parentheses), which has its origins in Etruscan numeral usage. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rn (page does not exist)">Template:Rn</a> used to represent 500 and 1,000 were most likely derived from <span class="Unicode">IƆ</span> and <span class="Unicode">CIƆ</span>, respectively, and subsequently influenced by assumed abbreviations.
</p><p>An extra <span class="Unicode">Ɔ</span> denoted 500, and multiple extra <span class="Unicode">Ɔ</span>s are used to denote 5,000, 50,000, etc. For example:
</p>
<table class="wikitable Unicode">

<tr>
<th>Base number
</th>
<td align="right">&#160;
</td>
<td align="right">CIƆ = 1,000
</td>
<td align="right">CCIƆƆ = 10,000
</td>
<td align="right">CCCIƆƆƆ = 100,000
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>1 extra Ɔ
</th>
<td align="right">IƆ = 500
</td>
<td align="right">CIƆƆ = 1,500
</td>
<td align="right">CCIƆƆƆ = 10,500
</td>
<td align="right">CCCIƆƆƆƆ = 100,500
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>2 extra Ɔs
</th>
<td align="right">IƆƆ = 5,000
</td>
<td align="right">&#160;
</td>
<td align="right">CCIƆƆƆƆ = 15,000
</td>
<td align="right">CCCIƆƆƆƆƆ = 105,000
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th>3 extra Ɔs
</th>
<td align="right">IƆƆƆ = 50,000
</td>
<td align="right">&#160;
</td>
<td align="right">&#160;
</td>
<td align="right">CCCIƆƆƆƆƆƆ = 150,000
</td></tr></table>
<p>Sometimes <span class="Unicode">CIƆ</span> was reduced to <span class="Unicode">ↀ</span> for 1,000. <a href="/wiki/John_Wallis" title="John Wallis">John Wallis</a> is often credited for introducing the symbol for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Infinity&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Infinity (page does not exist)">infinity</a> (modern <span class="Unicode">∞</span>), and one conjecture is that he based it on this usage, since 1,000 was <a href="/wiki/Hyperbole" title="Hyperbole">hyperbolically</a> used to represent very large numbers. Similarly, <span class="Unicode">IƆƆ</span> for 5,000 was reduced to <span class="Unicode">ↁ</span>; <span class="Unicode">CCIƆƆ</span> for 10,000 to <span class="Unicode">ↂ</span>; <span class="Unicode">IƆƆƆ</span> for 50,000 to <span class="Unicode">ↇ</span>; and <span class="Unicode">CCCIƆƆƆ</span> for 100,000 to <span class="Unicode">ↈ</span>.
<br style="clear:both;" />
</p>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="External_links">External links</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sister&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sister (page does not exist)">Template:Sister</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Sister&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Sister (page does not exist)">Template:Sister</a>
</p>
<ul>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.ubr.com/clocks/faq/iiii.html">FAQ No. 1 Why do clocks with Roman numerals use "IIII" instead of "IV"?: </a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.greatmathsgames.com/roman_numerals/roman_numerals.htm">Child friendly roman numerals webquest</a>
</li>

</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://sites.google.com/site/periczeljkosmederevoenglish/matematika/roman-ad-arabic-numerus-racio-et-vice-versa">Roman ad Arabic numerus racio et vice versa</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://cutedgesoft.com/our-products/cescnc-numerical-converter">CESCNC - a handy and easy-to use numeral converter</a>
</li>
<li> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://do-skoly.cz/en/courses/math/m-1/roman-arabic-numbers/calculator.aspx">Online converter of Roman numerals into Arabic numbers with check of correct notation and random tests</a>
</li>
</ul>

<div class="portal" role="navigation" id='p-tb' aria-labelledby='p-tb-label'>
	<h3 id='p-tb-label'>Tools</h3>
	<div class="body">
